case_vignette:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office complaining of right-sided upper abdominal pain for about 2 weeks. He is also complaining of subjective fever and malaise for the same duration. He has never been out of the United States. Additionally, he describes several episodes of bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain that resolved on their own a few months ago. Travel history is noncontributory. He has been sexually active with 3 male partners in the last year and uses a condom inconsistently. He was diagnosed with syphilis 4 months ago and was treated with a single shot of penicillin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the last 10 years and drinks 1–2 beers a day. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), blood pressure is 137/78 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. On physical examination, his liver is tender and palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin.
Laboratory test
 Hemoglobin  15 g/dL
 Leucocyte and differential  
Leucocyte count  12,500/mm3
Neutrophil  60%
Lymphocyte  31%
Eosinophil  1%
 Liver function test 
 ALT   100 U/L
 AST  95 U/L
ALP 220 U/L
CT scan of the abdomen shows a single cystic lesion on the right lobe of the liver.
question: What is the diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Infectious Diseases. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having right-sided upper abdominal pain for about 2 weeks, and I've also felt feverish and generally unwell for the same amount of time.
Have you noticed any changes in the color of your urine or stool?
No, I haven't mentioned any changes in the color of my urine or stool.
Have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite?
I haven't mentioned experiencing nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you taken any in the recent past?
Yes, I was treated with a single shot of penicillin for syphilis about 4 months ago.
Do you have a history of gallstones or gallbladder problems in your family?
I haven't mentioned anything about a family history of gallstones or gallbladder problems.
Have you had any recent imaging studies, like an ultrasound or CT scan, of your abdomen?
Yes, a CT scan of my abdomen showed a single cystic lesion on the right lobe of my liver.
Have you been exposed to any infectious agents or traveled to areas endemic with parasitic diseases?
I have never been out of the United States and my travel history doesn't contribute to my condition.
Do you have any known allergies or have you had allergic reactions to substances in the past?
I haven't mentioned any known allergies or past allergic reactions.
Final Diagnosis: Right hepatic lobe cystic lesion as seen on CT scan with accompanying symptoms suggestive of a hepatic cyst infection or abscess.

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A 35-year-old male presents with right-sided upper abdominal pain that has been ongoing for about 2 weeks. He also reports feeling feverish and generally unwell for the same duration, with a fever of about 101.6°F. He denies experiencing chills or night sweats and has not noticed any changes in the color of his urine, stool, or the whites of his eyes. He also denies experiencing nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite. The patient has not traveled outside of the United States and denies consuming anything potentially contaminated. He had several episodes of bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain a few months ago but did not seek medical attention for it. I've been having this pain on the right side of my upper belly for about 2 weeks and I've been feeling feverish and just overall unwell for the same amount of time.

Final Diagnosis: The patient is presenting with persistent upper right quadrant pain, fever, and a history of treated syphilis; therefore, a likely diagnosis is secondary syphilis with potential hepatic involvement. trial_2.summarized_conversation: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with a two-week history of pain on the right side of his upper belly and feeling feverish. A few months ago, he had episodes of bloody diarrhea. He has not traveled outside of the United States and does not recall being in contact with anyone who was sick. The patient is not taking any medications and was treated with a single shot of penicillin for syphilis four months ago. He denies any history of liver or gastrointestinal diseases, changes in appetite, or recent weight loss. The patient reports a fever of 38.7°C (101.6°F).
trial_2.vignette_frq: The diagnosis is likely hepatic abscess.
trial_2.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Acute cholecystitis (inflammation of the gallbladder).
